PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the person answering this questionnaire

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use extra sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires which have been prepared or projected are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Office of the Saskatchewan Archives at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRES

No. 2

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct as you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name ........................................ Henry Francis Hendek

2. Your address ........................................ 335 E. 7th Ave. Vancouver B.C. Canada

3. Date .................................................... May 16th 1955

4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country).
   Maple Lake, Minnesota, U.S.A. (45 miles west of Minneapolis)

5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   William Hendek, a farmer and Thresherman.

6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and Year).
   Oct. 1905

7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.

8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc).
   I was 26 yrs. old.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   I heard different stories about the west and I wanted to see for myself what it was like.

10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?).
    By hearing other people talk about it.
SASKATCHEWAN ARCHIVES QUESTIONNAIRE

PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

NOTE: Please print all proper names and place names in capital letters. If you are not sure the name is correct or if you have given it, please say so. It is quite acceptable to have someone else do the writing at your dictation.

1. Your full name: Henry Francis Hudek
2. Your address: 235, 677th Ave., Olivermere, B.C., Canada
3. Date: May 14th, 1955
4. Where were you born? (Give name of place and country)
   Quebec, Canada
5. What was your father's name and occupation?
   William Hudek, a farmer and Thatcherman
6. When did you come to Saskatchewan? (Give month and year)
   Oct. 1905
7. Mention any other places where you lived before coming to Saskatchewan, giving dates wherever possible.
8. How old were you when you first came to Western Canada? (You do not need to answer this question if you would rather not or you may use "I was a small child", "I was in my teens", etc.)
   Twenty-two years old
9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   I heard different stories about the west and wanted to see for myself what it was like.
10. How did you learn about the West? (Through other people? Reading about it?)
    By hearing other people talk about it.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They said they thought I was making a mistake.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Travelled with two friends, Peter Hance and Tim Flannigan.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train as far as Duck Lake, Sask., and then walked west 60 miles. Followed the old Hudson Bay trail most of the way.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

In travelling west we came to a Duckaboo village which was something new and very strange to us. Most of the people were wearing their old country clothes. We asked for food and shelter which we got. We were treated very well, they seemed pleased to help us.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

In a bunkhouse where our friend Ernest Forgette was working on the Duro ranch owned at that time by Thompson & Graves of North Battleford, Sask.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Sec. 22, Twp. 43, R. 10, West of 3rd.

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

With my mother and step brothers, Anthony Forgette and 3 half brothers on Sec. 6, Twp. 44, R. 10, West of 3rd meridian.

In 1910 I married Mary Welling and settled down on my own homestead.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How, after you came?

By farming on a small farm and doing odd jobs with a team like hauling ice to fill ice houses, hauling cord wood and hauling gravel for roads, and helping a carpenter and sometimes helping my stepfather in the shop who was a blacksmith by trade. After settling in Sask., I did some blacksmith work, built a couple small bridges and in the spring season I went farther south with horses and wagons to earn a little money.
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

They said they thought I was making a mistake.

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group)?

Travelled with my friends, Peter Hauer and Jim Chinnigar.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

By train as far as St. Louis, Mo., and then walked most of the way.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, settlements with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement, etc.)

On traveling most of the way, we met many Indians who were very friendly and wore nothing more than a loincloth. We asked for food and shelter, promising them old country clothes. We were treated very well, they seemed pleased to help us.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

I stayed at a friend's house where my friend Carroll Thompson was working on the Dunn Ranch owned at that time by Thompson and Shawver.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

See: 12 June 43, R. N. Waskop and

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

With my brothers and dad, Strathcona, 3 half brothers

On June 6, 1944, R. N. Waskop of Strathcona married Mary Shilling and settled down on my own homestead.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

By farming on a small farm and doing odd jobs with a team like hauling ice to list as known, hauling corn wood and hauling gravel for work and helping a carpenter and sometimes helping my stepfather on the land until we moved to Blacksmith Butte and an small bridge and often working on the railroad. We also worked on farms and wages to earn a little money.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?
Quite often and I still write.

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.
Married Miss Mary Spelling, Nov. 23, 1918. The district was called Euphemia but was changed to Stafford after the railroad came through.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
My brother and stepfather, Anthony Vorachek, and 3 half brothers also Mr. and Mrs. Herman Sther and their four small boys who settled south of Denholm, Sask., near the Saskatchewan river.

22. If other members of your family (brothers, sisters, parents, etc.) came West tell when they came and where they settled.
Peter Vance, my fosterin married my sister and they settled on the N.E. ¼ of Sec. 22, Twp. 43, R. 15, Sect. of 3rd meridian in 1905. In 1913 I purchased their homestead and they moved back to the U.S.A.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
When the Rail Road came through in 1913 I will never forget how strange it sounded to me to hear a train for the first time crossing my field.

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (for business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?
Yes we traveled about quite a bit, as most everybody was strange in the country and was anxious to make friends. In the fall of 1907 we built a Catholic church and the following year we built the Whiteberry school. I was elected trustee in both cases and did a considerable amount of driving around making arrangements. Sometimes I traveled with horse and cart and other times with a team and buggy and when necessary we used a team and wagon. I never rode horseback but my brothers did. The shortest distance we traveled to visit friends was to Denholm, Sask., about 25 or 30 miles. Mr. and Mrs. Herman Sther followed us out to Sask.
19. How often did you write to relatives or friends in your old home?

20. If you got married, give the name of your husband or wife along with the date and place of marriage.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommendation? If so, who?

22. Tell when they came and where they settled.

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?

24. Did you travel about much in the early years? (For business, attending church, visiting friends, etc.) How often? How far? By what means of travel?

25. Did you have any difficulty in making a living at first? How did you overcome these difficulties?

26. What was your occupation before coming to Saskatchewan?
25. When was the first car used in the community?
   I saw the first car on my farm about 1911 or 1912. Had my first ride in 1913
   and that was the first car in the community.

26. If you owned a car before 1914, when did you buy it? What make?

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?
   Radisson. Each 21 miles away, before we had a railroad in our own district.

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing, better means of travel, etc.)
   Stafford was much nearer and we did our trading there.

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Our Post Office called Lengum and a country store were only 2 miles away so we went there quite often and did not go to Radisson only when we needed lumber or something that the country store did not carry.

30. When (if ever) did people in your district first start going to town regularly on Saturdays?
   When the Rail Road came in and the town of Stafford strengthened in 1913.

31. When (if ever) did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues? What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.
   We first sent to Eaton's in Winnipeg in about 1907 or 1908 just small orders. And later on we bought most of our things on the farm from Eaton's.

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?
   We had the Stafford Rural Tel. Co.

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you make up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?
   I did not intend to make Sask. my home when I first came. I decided to make it my home after I was married Oct. 23, 1910. My parents and brothers were all in Sask. And my wife's 3 brothers all took up homesteads and neither of us felt like leaving Sask. after we had made new friends and were settled down among relatives.
25. When was the first car used by the community? My first car came in 1913.

26. Did you own a car before 1914? Yes, I did.

27. Where was your trading center? How far from your home?

28. Did you continue to trade there? (Indicate any changes due to new towns appearing) Better means of travel, etc.)

29. How often did you shop in the early days? Our Post Office called Everybody once a week.

30. What kind of articles did you buy in this way? Indicate also what fraction of your total purchases were by mail order and any changes in the proportion of purchases made by mail order since the pioneer period.

31. When did you first begin to buy through the mail order catalogues?

32. When did you first have a telephone and what company provided it?

33. When you came to Saskatchewan the first time was it with the idea of staying permanently? Or did you have up your mind after trying it out? When did you make this decision?

34. I did not intend to make Saskatchewan my home when I first came. I decided to make it my home after I was sick. And my wife's brothers all work up here.

35. My parents and brothers and I came back. And my wife's brothers all work up here.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

Yes, one growing family moved out because they thought they could do better at carpenter work. Another family moved to Saskatoon and several more bachelors also moved out. Reason unknown to me.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930s? Did many return?

Yes, one family moved to the U.S.A. about that time.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I was elected one of the councilors for the Redberry Municipality about the year 1909-10. Served four years as Councilor and four years as Reeve.

Elected trustee for White Berry school 1908 and later served on the Stafford School Board, acted as chairman most of the time. All told I served seventeen years as a trustee of the Catholic Church, starting about 1907-08 acting as chairman most of the time. President of the Redberry Agricultural Society as long as it lasted and Chairman of the Stafford Telephone Co. until retired in 1926.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were "first" to have or do something in the district mention it here giving dates wherever possible.

(Such as owning the first automobile, combine, organizing the first lodge, etc.)

I erected the first windmill in the district in the year of 1913-14.

Built the first big barn with hay loft and slings in 1913 and the house 24x32 in 1915.

Purchased my first Ford car in 1917 for $545.00 cash. Mr. J. Welling and I drove out among the farmers and sold shares on our Croft Elevator about the year 1914. I bought 7 of them myself.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts, Post Offices, villages, railway stations, creeks, hills, etc.). Try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name (2) origin and meaning of the name (3) date of its adoption (4) any changes in names since the first name was given, date and reason for change. Give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

John Kent a trustee and farmer suggested the name White Berry for our school. Mr. H. Ashcroft and I agreed to it and it was carried.

I was told that our first country Post Master came from Luxembourg and therefore our first Post Office was called Luxembourg.

(How Stafford got its name) When the C.H.R. Representative came along and wanted an option on my farm, he said the C.H.R. may buy it for a townsite. I told him that I could not afford to sell for the price he offered me, and during the transaction mentioned the word Stafford several times. The C.H.R. representative picked up the word Stafford and added my initial H to it and that made the word Stafford and that's how Stafford got its name.
34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1917? What reasons?

One person moved out because they thought they could do better at Carlisle.

35. Did many people move away during the 1920s? Did many return?

Yes, our family moved to the U.S.A. about that time.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public offices, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

A was elected one of the councilmen for the Redberry Municipality about the year 1929-1930. Served four years as Councilman and four years as Police Officer. Elected Trustee for White Barry school 1928 and later on served on the Board of School Board as Chairman of the Board. Purchased my first land on May 15th, 1932, and sold it to Shelly and I have since answered the summons and sold a Dairy on our Croft Blanton about the year 1934.

37. If you or any of your family or friends were interested in politics, combine, organizing the first lodge, (such as owning the first automobile), etc., etc.

Purchased the land on the district in the year 1932 and 1933.

38. How did the places in your community get their names? (School districts)

Post Offices, villages, railroad stations, creeks, hills, etc., try to give: (1) name and occupation of person suggesting place-name; (2) origin and meaning of the name; (3) date of its adoption; (4) any changes in names since the first use given; date and reason for change; give facts of new name as above in (1), (2), (3).

John Hafford and family applied the name White Barry for our School.

Some say that our first county Post Office came from Exeterburg and therefore on first post office was called Exeterburg.

After Hafford got the name, the C.R.R. Railroad came along and wanted an option on the name. He said the C.R.R. may buy it for a small sum but that I could not afford to sell for the price offered and during the transaction someone else bought the railroad and added my initials to it and that made the word Hafford and that's how Hafford got its name.
39. Questions regarding historical source materials:

Do you have in your possession or do you know the whereabouts of diaries, old letters, old posters and programs, minute books of community organizations, old pamphlets, old photographs, written recollections and reminiscences? (Describe).

My son E. P. Hudak asked me for old photos which are very likely in your possession at the present time. One is of an preaching outfit operating in 1885 and another is of the first picnic held in what was then Lumsden and is now the Hafford district. Photos taken July 4th, 1908.

Would you or the person who owns them either

(1) be willing to lend them to the Provincial Archivist for copying?

(2) be willing to present them to the Archives Division of the Legislative Library, Regina, or the Archives Office at the University in Saskatoon?

I sent them to my son E. P. Hudak. They may be in your possession now.

40. If you have children or grandchildren, please give their names, where they live and occupations.

My eldest son John Francis Hudak totally blind living in Queen Elizabeth Hall in Vancouver, B.C. Second son Henry Joseph Hudak living in Fort Collins, Colorado U.S.A. Third son Edward Philip Hudak, farmer at Hafford during summer months and instructor at the University in Saskatoon during the winter months. Elder daughter Margaret Amelia Sommers lives on farm at Hafford, Saskatchewan. Youngest daughter Mrs. Jane Elizabeth Kenny, a registered nurse, has accepted a position in St. Paul's Hospital as medical nursing instructor.

41. What do you think are the most important changes in your community since you first came West?

It's a thriving community now. The oxen and horses are a thing of the past and motors, tractors and electricity have taken their place.

When I homesteaded in 1905 there was no cattle ranch in the west and nothing else to be seen but the rolling prairie with here and there a little fluff.

Please give the names and addresses of other pioneers who could answer this questionnaire.

I think Andie Choque could answer most of the questions asked.

Hafford, Sask.
